review.title: Coordination Annotation Extension in the Penn Tree Bank
review.abstract: Coordination is an important and common syntactic construction which is not handled well by state of the art parsers. Coordinations in the Penn Treebank are missing internal structure in many cases, do not include explicit marking of the conjuncts and contain various errors and inconsistencies. In this work, we initiated manual annotation process for solving these issues. We identify the different elements in a coordination phrase and label each element with its function. We add phrase boundaries when these are missing, unify inconsistencies, and fix errors. The outcome is an extension of the PTB that includes consistent and detailed structures for coordinations. We make the coordination annotation publicly available, in hope that they will facilitate further research into coordination disambiguation.

metadata.title: Coordination Annotation Extension in the Penn Tree Bank

sections.text: In fact, it is so that most of them are able to survive themselves, and that they are able to survive themselves. (...) Most of them are not able to survive themselves. (...) sections.heading: 2 Background
sections.text: Coordination is a very common syntactic structure in which two or more elements are linked together. An example of a coordination structure is "Alice and Bob traveled to Mars." The elements (Alice and Bob) are called conjunctions and are called coordinators. Other coordinator words include or, nor and but. Any grammatical function can be coordinated. Examples: "[relatively active] ADJP but [unfocused] ADJP"; "[in] IN and [out] IN on the market." While it is common for the conjunctions to belong to the same syntactic category, coordinations of elements with different syntactic categories are also possible (e.g. "Alice visits Earth [tomorrow] NP or [in the next decade] PP." Less common coordinations are those with non-constituent elements. These are cases such as "equal or higher than" and coordinations of the type of argument cluster (e.g. "Alice visits 4 planets in 2014 and 3 more since then") and gapping (e.g. "Bob lives in the Earth and year).

sections.heading: 2.1 Elements of Coordination Structure
sections.text: While the canonical coordination cases involve conjunctions linked to a coordinator, other elements can also be part of the coordination structure: markers, connective adjectives, brackets, and shared arguments and modifiers. These elements are often part of the same syntactic phrase as the conjunctions and should be taken into account when noting the coordination structure. We will discuss the possible elements in a coordination set: split modifiers modifiers related to each of the conjunctions. For example, in "Venus density and mean temperature are very high," Venus is a split modifier of conjunction density "density" and "average temperature." Common arguments phrases that act as arguments for each of the conjunctions. In "Bob cleaned and fueled the spaceship Huston.," "the spaceship" and "Bob" are arguments of conjunction. "

sections.heading: 4 Extended Coordination Annotation
sections.text: The note of coordination by the PTB makes it difficult to identify coordinating phrases and distinguish the connections from the other parts of a coordination phrase. Furthermore, it contains various errors, inconsistencies and coordination phrases without an internal structure. We propose an improved presentation aimed at solving these problems and minimizing deviations from the original PTB trees.

sections.heading: 4.1 Explicit Function Marking
sections.text: We add function labels to non-terminal symbols of nodes participating in coordination structures. Function labels are identified by appending a -XXX suffix to the non-terminal symbol, where the XXX denotes the function of the node. Sentences that contain a coordination are identified by a CCP label. Nodes that are directly dominated by a CCP node, according to their function, receive one of the following labels: CC for coordinators, CO-ORD for conjunctions, MARK for markings5, CONN for connections and brackets, and SHARED for common modifiers / arguments. In the case of common elements, we only treat those that are within the coordination phrase. We do not assign function labels punctuation symbols and empty elements. For example, our annotations for the sentence. "he observed among his fellow students and, more importantly, among his officers and instructors COORDICS: COPPP CCICS and CODPP ICICS: ICS.

sections.heading: 4.2 Changes in Tree Structure
sections.text: As a guiding principle, we do not attempt to change the structure of the original PTB trees. Exceptions to this rule are cases where the structure is changed to provide internal structure when it is missing, as well as in determining systematic inconsistencies and occasional errors. 1. In flat coordination structures that include elements with more than one word, we add brackets to delimit elementary tensions. For example, we add brackets to delimit the subjunctive "Chief Executive Officer." The complete phrase 5both, either between the first, not only, and the death structure is: (NP-CCP (NN-COORD Chairman) and) (NP-COORD Chief Executive Officer). 2. Comparative quantitative phrases ("$5 or less") are analyzed inconsistently in the PTB. If necessary, we add an additional bracket with a QP label so that they are consistently analyzed as "$5 [or less] QP."

sections.heading: 5 The Annotation Process
sections.text: Some of the changes can be made automatically, while others require human judgment. Our annotation process combines automatic rules and manual annotations carried out by a special annotator trained for this purpose.

sections.heading: 5.1 Explicit marking of coordination phrases
sections.text: We consider a phrase to be a coordination phrase if it contains a coordinator and at least one phrase on each side of the coordinator, as opposed to coordinators acting as a discourse marker or introducing brackets that appear as the first element in the phrase.

sections.heading: 5.2 Assigning internal structure to flat coordinations
sections.text: For the rest of the flat coordinations (3498 cases) that we commented on manually, the analysis extended to: "[General] NNP [Electric] NNP [Co.] NNS [and] CC [Lawyers] NRB." The commentator is expected to perform the analysis: "[General Electric Co.] [executives] [and] [lawyers]." We then add brackets around multitoken elements (e.g. "General Electric Co."), and put the label after the syntactic structure. The comment was made while ignoring the internal structures given in the NP bracketing extension of Vadas and Curran.

sections.heading: 5.3 Annotating roles within coordination phrases
sections.text: There is only one coordinator and two siblings in the coordinated phrase, both marked as conjunctival impulses: 6If the conjunctival impulses are at the POS level, a corresponding syntactic label is set, for example: (NP) CCP (NN-COORD head) (CC-CC and) (NN-COORD-Schuler) (D-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP-EP) (EP-EP) (EP-EP) (EP-EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP (EP) (EP (EP) EP (EP) (EP) (EP) (EP (EP) (EP) EP (EP) EP (EP) (EP (EP) EP (EP (EP) EP (EP) EP) (EP (EP) (EP) EP (EP) (EP (EP) EP (EP (EP) EP (EP) EP (EP) EP) (EP (EP) (EP) EP) (EP (EP (EP (EP) EP (EP) EP (EP) EP) EP (EP) (EP (

sections.heading: 5.4 Handling inconsistencies and errors
sections.text: We change the structure so that such ADVPs and markers appear right before a VP coordination phrase. Quantity sentences that contain two conjunctions with a second conjunction of more, less, so that two and more are automatically detected and consolidated by adding an additional layer. Errors in conjunctions are found during the manual annotation that is made for categorization. If the manual annotation contains a conjunction that is originally a combination of two sibling phrases, we add additional brackets and name the new level according to the syntactic structure.

sections.heading: 6 Annotator Agreement
sections.text: We evaluate the resulting corpus with intercommentators agreement for coordination sets with inner structure as well as agreement with the flat conjunctions commented in the NP bracket comments by Vadas and Curran (2007).

sections.heading: 6.1 Inter-annotator agreement
sections.text: To test the intercommentary agreement, we were joined by an additional linguist who commented on 1000 out of 7823 coordination sentences with an inner structure. We measured the number of coordination sentences where the spans are inconsistent at least in one conjunction. In 92.8% of sentences, the commentators originally agreed. After the revision, the agreement increased to 98.1%. The discrepancies occurred in semantically ambiguous cases. For example, "potato salad, baked beans and custard plus coffee or iced tea" was marked differently by the two commentators, one regarding "custard" as the last conjunction and the other as "custard plus coffee or iced tea."

sections.heading: 6.2 Agreement with NP Bracketing for flat coordinations
sections.text: The NP bracketing extension of Vadas and Curran (2007) includes internal structures for flat NP phrases in the PTB that are marked with the NML tag. For example, in (NP (NNP Air) (NNP Force) (NN Treaty)), "Air Force" is considered an independent entity and is therefore delimited with the NML tag: (NP (NNP Air) (NNP Force) (NN Treaty). As already mentioned, 48% (1655 phrases) of the overall NP coordination was clearly delimited in this endeavour.8 For this, the agreement on conjunctions extends to 88% in the way characterized by our commentators. The disagreements existed in cases where a modifier is ambiguous.

sections.heading: 7 Experiments
sections.text: This year it is more than ever before.

sections.heading: 8 Conclusions
sections.text: Coordination is a common and important syntactic phenomenon that poses a major challenge for the automatic syntactical annotation. Unfortunately, the current state of coordination annotation is missing in the PTB. We present a version of the PTB with improved annotation for the coordination structure. TheCOORD b) (CC and) (NP-COORD c)) (PP d))). If you only consider the syntactic labels, there is only the error of the coordination span. If you consider the coordination roles, there are two additional errors - the missing labels for a and d.new annotation adds to the hitherto flat NPs structure, standardizes inconsistencies, fixes errors and identifies the role of different participants in the coordination structure in terms of coordination. We provide our annotation to the NLP community. This resource is a necessary first step towards better clarification of coordination structures in syntactic particles.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: This work was supported by the Allen Institute for Artificial Intelligence and the German Research Foundation via the German-Israeli Project Cooperation (DIP, funding DA 1600 / 1-1).

referenceMentions.context: The Penn Treebank (PTB) (Marcus et al., 1993) is perhaps the most commonly used resource for training and evaluating syntax-based natural language processing systems.

The Penn Treebank (PTB) (Marcus et al., 1993) is perhaps the most commonly used resource for training and evaluating syntax-based natural language processing systems. Despite its widespread adoption and undisputed usefulness, some of the annotations in PTB are not optimal, and could be improved. The work of Vadas and Curran (2007) identified and addressed one such annotation deficiency – the lack of internal structure in base NPs.
As noted by Hogan (2007), coordination annotation in the PTB are not consistent, include errors, and lack internal structure in many cases (Hara et al., 2009; Hogan, 2007; Shimbo and Hara, 2007).
As noted by Hogan (2007), coordination annotation in the PTB are not consistent, include errors, and lack internal structure in many cases (Hara et al., 2009; Hogan, 2007; Shimbo and Hara, 2007).
As noted by Hogan (2007), coordination annotation in the PTB are not consistent, include errors, and lack internal structure in many cases (Hara et al.

As noted by Hogan (2007), coordination annotation in the PTB are not consistent, include errors, and lack internal structure in many cases (Hara et al., 2009; Hogan, 2007; Shimbo and Hara, 2007). Another issue is that PTB does not mark whether a punctuation is part of the coordination or not. This was resolved by Maier et al. (2012) which annotated punctuation in the PTB .

These errors, inconsistencies, and in particular the lack of internal structural annotation turned researchers that were interested specifically in coordination disambiguation away from the PTB and towards much smaller, domain specific efforts such as the Genia Treebank (Kim et al., 2003) of biomedical texts (Hara et al.
, 2003) of biomedical texts (Hara et al., 2009; Shimbo and Hara, 2007).
“Bob lives in Earth and Alice in Saturn”) (Dowty, 1988).
NPs without internal structure The PTB guidelines (Bies et al., 1995) avoid giving any structure to NPs with nominal modifiers.
Some are related to flat coordinations (Hogan, 2007).

We use the stateof-the-art Berkeley parser (Petrov et al., 2006), and compare the original PTB annotations (including Vadas and Curran’s base-NP bracketing – PTB+NPB) to the coordination annotations in this work (PTB+NPB+CCP).

metadata.abstractText: Coordination is an important and common syntactic construction which is not handled well by state of the art parsers. Coordinations in the Penn Treebank are missing internal structure in many cases, do not include explicit marking of the conjuncts and contain various errors and inconsistencies. In this work, we initiated manual annotation process for solving these issues. We identify the different elements in a coordination phrase and label each element with its function. We add phrase boundaries when these are missing, unify inconsistencies, and fix errors. The outcome is an extension of the PTB that includes consistent and detailed structures for coordinations. We make the coordination annotation publicly available, in hope that they will facilitate further research into coordination disambiguation. 1
